newsitem.title: GERMANY: SOCCER-BECKENBAUER WORRIED ABOUT CASH IN ENGLISH GAME.
newsitem.headline: SOCCER-BECKENBAUER WORRIED ABOUT CASH IN ENGLISH GAME.

text.p: Franz Beckenbauer is worried the influx of cash in the English game could destroy the international market for players.

Lucrative new television deals have given English league clubs extra money to buy top players. Several -- most notably Manchester United -- have increased their spending power further by raising funds on the London stock market.
In contrast, none of the big German clubs have gone public and continue to rely on fans, sponsors and television deals for their income.

In an interview with the German magazine Sport Bild, Bayern Munich chairman Beckenbauer said: "(The English clubs) can do more because many of the clubs can go to the stock exchange to get capital and protect themselves.
"This puts up the prices (for players) internationally. The players go where they can earn the most...The Italians will catch up. Spain and Germany have reached the Italian level.
"Everywhere you look the prices are going up. One day the whole market will collapse."
